items.title: KLF5 enables dichotomous lineage programs in pancreatic cancer via the AAA+ ATPase coactivators RUVBL1 and RUVBL2
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 15 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66007-0 RUVBL1 and RUVBL2 are AAA+ ATPases that are involved in transcriptional regulation. Here, the authors discover that RUVBL1/2 regulation of KLF5 modulates both classical and basal-like transcriptional lineage programs in pancreatic cancer.

items.title: Advanced SQUID-on-lever scanning probe for high-sensitivity magnetic microscopy with sub-100-nm spatial resolution
authors: Timur Weber, Daniel Jetter, Jan Ullmann, Simon A. Koch, Simon F. Pfander, Katharina Kress, Andriani Vervelaki, Boris Gross, Oliver Kieler, Ute Drechsler, Priya R. Baral, Arnaud Magrez, Reinhold Kleiner, Armin W. Knoll, Martino Poggio, and Dieter Koelle
items.summary: Nanoscale superconducting quantum interference devices (SQUIDs) integrated on scanning probes are important for high-resolution magnetic imaging at low temperatures. Progress has been limited by a lack of robust sensors that can both be fabricated on the wafer scale and provide the highest spatial resolution. The authors combine optical lithography and focused-ion-beam milling to produce niobium nano-SQUIDs on silicon cantilevers, achieving high spatial resolution and sensitivity in magnetic fields of up to 0.5 T at 4.2 K. These sensors can image individual magnetic skyrmions and nanoscale magnetization patterns, significantly expanding the applicability of scanning SQUID microscopy. [Phys. Rev. Applied 24, 054041] Published Fri Nov 14, 2025

items.title: Sinking cities: how China is moving subsidence research forward
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03529-z Faced with the double threat of rising sea levels and subsiding ground, researchers are devising plans to bring communities back from the brink.

items.title: Three research stars fighting to protect coastlines
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03531-5 Coastal cities and communities are being hit hard by climate change. These researchers are finding ways to build resilience.

items.title: Why I moved my research to China from Germany: a biologist’s experience
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03762-6 Shaw prize winner Wolfgang Baumeister is one of many international researchers recruited by Chinese institutes.

items.title: A Chinese AI model taught itself basic physics — what discoveries could it make?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03659-4 A tool called AI-Newton can derive scientific laws from raw data, but is some way from developing human-like reasoning.

items.title: The future of AI
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03701-5 Artificial intelligence is flying high. Nature asked leading innovators what they think will happen next.

items.title: Who will fill the climate-data void left by the Trump administration?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03532-4 US withdrawal from monitoring projects has sent the world scrambling for alternatives.

items.title: Spaceport mementos
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-03688-z A badge of honour.

items.title: Author Correction: Non-temperature environmental drivers modulate warming-induced 21st-century permafrost degradation on the Tibetan Plateau
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65187-z Author Correction: Non-temperature environmental drivers modulate warming-induced 21st-century permafrost degradation on the Tibetan Plateau

items.title: DFT calculations and theory do not support enantiospecificity in NMR J-coupling constants
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66247-0 DFT calculations and theory do not support enantiospecificity in NMR J-coupling constants

items.title: CarbaDetector: a machine learning model for detecting carbapenemase-producing Enterobacterales from disk diffusion tests
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-66183-z Carbapenems are last-resort antibiotics, but resistance is rising due to hydrolyzing enzymes called carbapenemases. The authors present a machine learning algorithm and web-app to rapidly predict carbapenemase-production in Enterobacterales.

items.title: Electrodeposition of magnetic nanonetworks featuring triangular motifs and parallel ridges on a macroscopic scale
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-65589-z Self-organized growth often suffers from a lack of long-range order in preparing large-area nanostructures. Here, the authors develop a direct electrochemical growth technique for preparing ordered magnetic networks without the use of templates.

items.title: Biomimetic Janus membrane with spongy channels for directional liquid transport
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64964-0 Directional liquid transport driven by the asymmetric properties of Janus fiber membranes has been used in oil-water separation and moisture management but showing limited water transport efficiency. Here, the authors optimize the porous channels of directional liquid transport Janus fiber membranes by integrating longitudinal channels with a horizontal network.

items.title: A preserved TGFβ cytostatic response through DLD-mediated metabolic modulation undermines anti-TGFβ therapy in gastric cancer
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64997-5 The role of TGFβ in cancer is paradoxical and context-dependent. Here, the authors discover that a preserved, DLD-mediated metabolic suppression by TGFβ undermines anti-TGFβ therapy, promoting gastric cancer growth.

items.title: Van-der-Waals-forces-modulated graphene-P-phenyl-graphene carbon allotropes
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-64971-1 Here the authors report an allotrope to the nanocarbon family, Graphene-P-phenyl-Graphene, for potassium-ion batteries.

items.title: Scalable ruthenium core–shell hydrogen catalyst for efficient and robust proton-exchange membrane electrolyser
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02405-5 Green hydrogen production often needs Pt-based electrolysers; however, their high cost and lack of scalability hinder uptake. Here a core–shell Ru-based electrolyser is demonstrated for acidic hydrogen evolution and demonstrates a low overpotential and Pt-like stability, as well as scalability to a 200 cm2 device.

items.title: Nanoscale domains govern local diffusion and ageing within fused-in-sarcoma condensates
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 14 November 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-02077-x Single-molecule tracking reveals nanoscale domains within fused-in-sarcoma condensates. These nanodomains migrate to the condensate surface during ageing, seeding amyotrophic lateral sclerosis-linked fibrils, a process accelerated by small-molecule drugs.
